Assuming I understand functors correctly, docs#RingHom.mapMatrix (and even docs#RingEquiv.mapMatrix) show that Matrix n m is a functor in docs#RingCat. Does the definition of the actual functor (docs#CategoryTheory.Functor) exist somewhere?

I also think the following are functors but they don't have any theorems about mapping ring homs:

  • FractionRing
  • QuadraticAlgebra · a b (not sure if it's an actual functor since a and b also need to be put through the ring hom)
  • AdjoinRoot · p (p also needs to be mapped using the ring hom)

Do any of the above have a theorem similar to Matrix's docs#RingHom.mapMatrix ?

On mobile right now so I cannot check, but it is possible that the literal def you are looking for (sai for FractionRing) is not there. On the other hand, there surely is a more general version, for example the universal property of localization is there, and it gives the induced map on fraction field.
I am pretty sure not that much is spelled using category theory language though
But note that the fraction ring is not really a functor (it needs the morphism to be injective)
docs#Mat might have something nearby? nevermind, that guess was wrong

Riccardo Brasca said:

But note that the fraction ring is not really a functor (it needs the morphism to be injective)

(then it is a functor if you restrict to the injective maps, but idk if we have this machinery in the category theory and/or whether or not this is a useful construction to have)
What is the advantage of building a matrix functor?

Kenny Lau said:

What is the advantage of building a matrix functor?

I needed the property α ≃+* β → Matrix m n α ≃+* Matrix m n β so I thought to myself "oh, the property I'm looking for is that Matrix is a functor", then I went to Loogle/LeanSearch to search for Matrix, "functor" and it didn't find it.

Maybe a good first step would be to mention the word "functor" in the docstring of docs#RingEquiv.mapMatrix, to increase discoverability.

Feel free to make a PR to mathlib adding what you think the docstring should say! That's how the system works.

But this statement is not that the map is a functor, that would be that you can go from a morphism to a morphism, rather than from an isomorphism to an isomorphism. Here I think you would be best off searching for that construction simply by searching for a term of that type using loogle or even exact?.

Normally we wouldn’t use the word “property” for a data-carrying map. Instead, you are looking for a specific functor on the “core” groupoid, whose morphisms are the invertible morphisms in the category of rings. However, in this case, it is just a restriction of a functor on the usual category.

Often in mathlib, we define the maps underlying certain functors separately. This way, in applications that don’t need much categorical sophistication, we don’t need to import the heavy categorical machinery.
